mentions.context: Scripts used to perform these analyses are available as a platform-independent R package, net4pg, available on CRAN under GPL-3 license [73].
The Jurkat cell line dataset was produced as part of a study by Sheynkman et al. [31].
The Jurkat transcriptome dataset was obtained by paired-end RNA sequencing on an Illumina HiSeq 2000 system generating 2 × 200 base-long reads.

The Proline software [71] was used for post-search PSM validation, applying the following prefilters: (i) PSMs with a score difference < 0.1 were considered of equal score and assigned to the same rank (pretty rank), (ii) only a single best-scoring PSM was retained for each query (single PSM per rank), and (iii) minimum peptide length ≥ 7 amino acids.

Then, the Ensembl reference protein database (GRCh38 and GRCm39 for human and mouse samples, respectively) was filtered to only retain proteins for which the corresponding transcript is expressed in the sample.

A companion R code is provided as an R package (net4pg, available on CRAN, see the "Availability of data and materials" section) implementing all the above-described steps, including (i) generating the adjacency matrix, (iii) calculating CCs, and (iii) visualizing CCs as bipartite graphs.
Parameters used for Mascot (or MS-GF+) searches are reported in Additional file 1: Table S14.
We provide an R package (net4pg, available on CRAN, see the "Availability of data and materials" section) to implement this type of post hoc filtering strategy.
PSMs were identified using Mascot search (version 2.6), if not otherwise specified.
Unless otherwise specified, StringTie output was used for downstream analyses.

PSMs were first validated using the Proline software with the following prefilters: (i) PSMs with a score difference < 0.1 were considered of equal score and assigned to the same rank (pretty rank), (ii) only a single best-scoring PSM was retained per query (single PSM per rank), and (iii) minimum peptide length ≥ 7 amino acids.
B Size and overlap of the reference human Ensembl protein database (full protein DB) and the sample-specific reduced transcriptome-informed protein databases (reduced protein DB).
Database searches were performed using the Mascot search engine.
Database searches were performed using the MS-GF+ search engine.
We provide an R package (net4pg, available on CRAN, see the "Availability of data and materials" section) to implement this type of post hoc filtering strategy.

A companion R code is provided as an R package (net4pg, available on CRAN, see the "Availability of data and materials" section) implementing all the above-described steps, including (i) generating the adjacency matrix, (iii) calculating CCs, and (iii) visualizing CCs as bipartite graphs.

For each sample, two sample-specific reduced versions of the Ensembl database were obtained, based on expressed transcripts from either StringTie or Cufflinks transcript quantification (Additional file 2: Fig. S1A).

MS/MS spectra were assigned searching either the reference human Ensembl protein database (full protein DB) or a subset of the reference database, generated based on transcript expression (reduced protein DB), using the Mascot software.

A companion R code is provided as an R package (net4pg, available on CRAN, see the "Availability of data and materials" section) implementing all the above-described steps, including (i) generating the adjacency matrix, (iii) calculating CCs, and (iii) visualizing CCs as bipartite graphs.

Since the reduced database was constructed as a simple subset of the Ensembl human database and considered only a single best-scoring peptide for each spectrum (see the "Proteome analysis" section), we could easily map each spectrum match between the two searches.

Raw reads were downloaded from public repositories and processed on the Galaxy platform available at https://usegalaxy.org/ [66] using common workflows for read preprocessing and alignment to identify expressed transcripts (Additional file 1: Table S13).
Protein identifications were reported as protein groups, as defined in the Proline software.
Finally, transcriptome-informed filtering was performed using an in-house R code now available on CRAN as an R package (net4pg, see the "Availability of data and materials" section).
When specified, MS-GF+ [70] (version 2017.07.21) searches were performed on Galaxy [66] (https://usegalaxy. eu).
Decoy sequences were generated by reversing target sequences running the Perl script provided with the Mascot software.
A detailed description of the package usage is also available as a vignette on CRAN.
The one-to-one transcript-toprotein correspondence is guaranteed by the use of Ensembl as the reference protein database in proteomics and for genome annotation in transcriptomics.

Then, we generated reduced databases for use in MS/MS searches by retaining from the Ensembl human protein database only proteins for which transcripts were expressed in the sample-matched transcriptome (see the "Construction of reduced transcriptome-informed protein databases for MS/MS searches" section) (Fig. 1A,B).

Much fewer spectra were available for the MouseColon sample and slightly fewer for the Jurkat sample, which, interestingly, also presented a greater difference in score cutoffs between the full and reduced databases.
Scripts used to perform these analyses are available as a platform-independent R package, net4pg, available on CRAN under GPL-3 license [73].
Raw spectra were downloaded from public repositories and processed automatically using the Mascot Distiller software (version 2.7, Matrix Science).
Initially, two common strategies for transcriptome assembly and quantification were applied: StringTie [68] and Cufflinks [69].

First, sequencing adapters and low-quality (Phred score < 20) read ends were trimmed off using TrimGalore (https://www.bioinformatics.babraham.ac.uk/projects/trim_ galore/), and reads shorter than 20 bp after trimming were discarded.
Score cutoffs obtained by target-decoy competition for FDR control at 1% for the full (reference Ensembl database) or reduced (transcriptome-informed reduced database) database searches.
Score cutoffs obtained by target-decoy competition for FDR control at 1% for the full (reference Ensembl database) or reduced (transcriptome-informed reduced database) database searches.
Finally, transcriptome-informed filtering was performed using an in-house R code now available on CRAN as an R package (net4pg, see the "Availability of data and materials" section).

We compared valid peptide-spectrum matches (PSMs) obtained from the MS/ MS search against the whole Ensembl human database (referred to as the "full database") or against the sample-specific reduced database (referred to as the "reduced database") at 1% FDR, as estimated by TDC.

For this study, the post hoc filtering strategy on PSMs obtained from searching the target-only full Ensembl protein database was used, followed by the BH procedure for FDR control, to allow comparison with the approach searching target-only reduced transcriptome-informed protein databases, followed by the BH procedure for FDR control.
Decoy sequences were generated by reversing target sequences running the Perl script provided with the Mascot software.

Searches were performed against two different concatenated target-decoy databases: either the original Ensembl protein database (human GRCh38 and mouse GRCm39 for human and the mouse samples, respectively) or a reduced version of it containing only proteins for which the transcript is expressed (as described in the "Construction of reduced transcriptome-informed protein databases for MS/MS searches" section).
For the number of protein-level identifications, we used the number of protein groups, as defined by the Proline software.
Scripts used to perform these analyses are available as a platform-independent R package, net4pg, available on CRAN under GPL-3 license [73].

Initially, two common strategies for transcriptome assembly and quantification were applied: StringTie [68] and Cufflinks [69].
Comparison of PSM scores obtained for the same spectrum in the full database and in the reduced database search, using MS-GF+ search engine.
Comparison of PSM scores obtained for the same spectrum in the full database and in the reduced database search, using Mascot search engine.
First, peptide identifications were obtained by searching the full reference protein database, and validated using the Proline software, as described in the "Proteome analysis" section.
Finally, transcriptome-informed filtering was performed using an in-house R code now available on CRAN as an R package (net4pg, see the "Availability of data and materials" section).

Briefly, we first processed transcriptome datasets and identified the set of transcripts expressed in each sample using StringTie, a common transcriptome assembly method (see the "Transcriptome analysis" section).

For each sample, two sample-specific reduced versions of the Ensembl database were obtained, based on expressed transcripts from either StringTie or Cufflinks transcript quantification (Additional file 2: Fig. S1A).

For each sample, two sample-specific reduced versions of the Ensembl database were obtained, based on expressed transcripts from either StringTie or Cufflinks transcript quantification (Additional file 2: Fig. S1A).

This file was then converted into an incidence matrix, with proteins along the columns and peptides along the rows, using the crosstab function from the GNU datamash program (http://www.gnu.org/software/datamash).

Briefly, samplematched transcriptomes were processed as described above, and the subsets of transcripts expressed at FPKM > 1 were identified according to the StringTie or Cufflinks algorithms for transcript assembly and quantification.

Then, preprocessed reads were aligned against the corresponding reference genome (assembly GRCh38 for human samples and GRCm39 for the mouse sample) by the splice-aware STAR aligner [67] in default mode, using the Ensembl reference gene models for splice junctions.

To investigate how searching reduced transcriptome-informed protein databases affects proteomic identifications, we used four different samples (hereafter referred to as Jurkat, Lung, MouseColon, and Spleen) for which matched transcriptome and proteome data were publicly available (Additional file 1: Table S1).

Four samples for which matched transcriptome and proteome were publicly available were analyzed: human healthy lung and spleen tissues (referred to as Lung and Spleen), a Jurkat cell line (referred to as Jurkat), and mouse colon stem cells (referred to as MouseColon).

Briefly, samplematched transcriptomes were processed as described above, and the subsets of transcripts expressed at FPKM > 1 were identified according to the StringTie or Cufflinks algorithms for transcript assembly and quantification.

Unless otherwise specified, all downstream analyses were performed using the reduced transcriptome-informed database built according to expressed transcripts identified by StringTie, which is more recent than Cufflinks.

For these analyses, PSMs obtained from target-only protein databases, appended with the same database of common contaminant sequences, were used and searched applying the same Mascot parameters as before.

Indeed, even more identifications were lost when using a further reduced protein database, such as that generated on the basis of the smaller set of expressed transcripts identified by Cufflinks, an alternative method of transcriptome assembly (Additional file 2: Fig. S1).

We confirmed this observation at various levels of FDR control (0.5%, 1%, 5%) and for four different samples: three human-derived samples-healthy tissues (Lung and Spleen) or a cell line (Jurkat)-and one mouse-derived sample-flow cytometry sorted colon stem cells (MouseColon).

Four samples for which matched transcriptome and proteome were publicly available were analyzed: human healthy lung and spleen tissues (referred to as Lung and Spleen), a Jurkat cell line (referred to as Jurkat), and mouse colon stem cells (referred to as MouseColon).

Unless otherwise specified, all downstream analyses were performed using the reduced transcriptome-informed database built according to expressed transcripts identified by StringTie, which is more recent than Cufflinks.

Then, preprocessed reads were aligned against the corresponding reference genome (assembly GRCh38 for human samples and GRCm39 for the mouse sample) by the splice-aware STAR aligner [67] in default mode, using the Ensembl reference gene models for splice junctions.

MS/MS spectra were assigned searching either the reference human Ensembl protein database (full protein DB) or a subset of the reference database, generated based on transcript expression (reduced protein DB), using the Mascot software.

To build bipartite graphs of proteomic identifications, first, a tab-separated file containing identified peptides and all proteins they map on (one protein per line) was generated based on the output of PSM validation by the Proline software.

Ambiguous protein identifications can be visually inspected by taking the CC of interest, extracting all specific and shared peptides mapping to the CC protein members from the incidence matrix and plotting peptide-to-protein mappings as bipartite graphs, using the igraph R package.

For the sake of clarity, we emphasize that the few spectra that matched only sequences in the reduced database (indicated as "no match, target" or "no match, decoy" in Fig. 2A, Additional file 2: Fig. S2A, S3A, S4, S5, S6, and S7) do not contradict this observation; they can all be explained by reallocation and the prefilters applied for Fig. 2 Lower cutoff for FDR control in the reduced database generates additional identifications (Jurkat).
